body.value:
The Group module is a powerful tool that allows you to create and manage communities on a website developed with Drupal. It provides advanced user and content management functionalities for specific groups of people.

It allows you to define and configure different groups on the website, establish custom permissions and roles for each group, and associate corresponding users with each group. This means that users can access and participate in specific functionalities and content of their group, while the rest of the site can have different content and settings.

Some key features of the Group module include:

  • Group creation: It allows site administrators to create different groups and define their settings, such as permissions, roles, and custom fields. User association: It allows adding users to the corresponding group, giving them access to specific group functionalities and content. 
  • Membership management: You can invite users to join a specific group and set roles and permissions for each member. This allows you to control who has access and what actions they can perform within the group. 
  • Privacy and access control: It allows defining privacy levels for groups and their content, such as public, private, or hidden, as well as setting permissions for different user roles within each group. 
  • Group content: Group facilitates the creation and management of exclusive content for each group. You can have different types of content (such as articles, events, discussions) that are only visible and editable by members of the corresponding group. 
  • Collaboration features: It offers tools to facilitate collaboration within groups, such as discussion forums, group blogs, file management, and events. 
  • Integration with other modules: Group integrates with other popular Drupal modules, such as Views, Rules, and Panels, allowing you to further customize the appearance and behavior of groups. 
  • Group hierarchy: The Group module allows you to create group hierarchies, which means you can have parent groups and subgroups within them. This is useful when you want to organize groups into categories or levels.

It's important to note that the Group module was originally developed as a contributed module for Drupal 7 and Drupal 8. However, starting from Drupal 9, the Group module was incorporated into the Drupal core, which means it comes included by default in the base installation of Drupal 9 and later versions, making it easier to use and maintain.
